content.description: Standard NRG climbing on ledges and pockets with slopey holds from the 3rd to 4th bolt.
content.protection: 5 bolts to shared anchor with route to the right.
content.location: See beta photo below.  Climbs through a less than vertical section to a small bulge.

content.description:
Don't read this if you don't want beta.

The first 3-4 bolts are the crux, after 4th bolt no hands rest (ledge), move fast to anchors.

Be prepared to clip from poor holds (considering the grade... crimpers slopers)
content.protection: bring 8-9 quicks plus something for the anchors
content.location: this route is to the left of Orange Oswald. rap the route.

content.description: Short corner between hippie dreams and fabulous groupies fun moderate trad route..ends at anchors of  fabulous groupies
content.protection: trad rack.  A #4 Camalot is nice to have for the middle.  A red TCU protects well under a flake as your last piece of pro.  Traverse left to FG anchors or right to HD anchors.
content.location: between hippie dreams and fabulous groupies

content.description:
30 feet of good gear with fingers and thin hands. Continue past to a ledge, climb through a 15 foot offwidth section, pull under and out the crack leading through the roof to the top.

By far the best gear line in Summersville.
content.protection:
Bolted anchor.

Bring a #1 or #2 for the final roof.

Rack up to a #3 with some long runners for the offwidth.
content.location: Obvious crack to the right of Moon Pie Deluxe and Barfing Butterflies.

content.description:
Climb located 2 climbs right of Orange Oswald.

P1: Sport 6 bolts
Start from the vegetated ledge and work your way up the face past a bulge or two to the anchors.
content.location: At the far left side of Orange Oswald Wall at a vegetated ledge.

content.description:
Mantle up onto a ledge and then standup and clip the first bolt. From here it's exactly 6 moves to the dyno throw to a sloper. Great pockets and incut crimps up a short steep wall.

This route may seem harder depending on your height so I've neglected to use the book grade of 11b and instead opted for a 5.11 grade.

This route was bolted in the unfortunate location of the common bathroom break for many a Orange Oswald climber.
content.location: Walk to the end of the Orange Oswald wall, take a left and look immediately up and left and you'll find this short, burly route.

climbs.name: She got the Bosch, I got Drilled

content.description: Better than Orange Oswald.  Fun climbing through small roof sections.  Holds are all there and the sequences are relatively straight-forward.
content.location: Starts just left of a right-facing arete.

content.description: Start slightly to the right of a thin tree on good holds, passing 2 bolts, to reach a slabby section.  At the base of the slabby section, head up and left using small but positive holds and high steps (technical crux).   After clipping the top bolt on the slab, head up into the overhang.  After a couple jugs, you'll hit a reachy move to another jug as you pull the lip of the overhang (redpoint crux).   After you pull the roof, it's smooth sailing from here.
content.location: This is the next to last sport line that you will encounter as you walk right along the Orange Oswald Wall.

content.description: Start at a shallow, left-facing feature and follow a bolt line up until you reach a traverse on heavily chalked holds.  This is the crux.  There is a bit of a runout to the anchors, but it's on much easier climbing.
content.location: This is the namesake route of the wall.  Downhill climber's right from the classic cruiser Hippie Dreams.  When facing the route, look for a shallow left-facing feature at ground level.  For reference, up and to the left, you should see a clean orange dihedral a couple routes over.

content.description: Climb the short left facing corner through a few tricky opening moves to better holds above and then carefully climb to the high first bolt. Proceed through the next few bolts on good holds between long stretches. The grade drops at the top as you move up through large chicken heads to the anchors.
content.protection: It takes one piece of gear at the bottom then 7 bolts to the anchors
content.location: Start ten feet right of Orange Oswald at a steep left facing ramp. As of Aug-2011 the start was marked with the chalk letters PDS which I assume at the equippers initials.

content.description:
Well, there was a fun move, then it got thin and not fun. Not for the short climber. (*Edited to Add, Michaels climbing partner that day is about 5'2" and she suffered up this climb, although we did think it was Scoot Your Muffin (5.10b).)

Bolts are poorly placed (*Edited to add and hard to clip if you are short, best to 'pink poin' this one.)

Roof system is funky and awkward at best, (*Edited to add, I did not climb this one, but I was just to the left climbing a few routes and Michael(A competent 5.12 climber and guide in the New) was suffering though this roof.)
content.location: 2nd farthest climb to the right on this awesome wall.

content.description: Easy slabby climbing leads to a big ledge. Clip the second bolt then pull through thin moves to third bolt where the climbing gets easier.
content.location: See beta photo below. Climbs left of a split tree. A huge ledge is gained after the first bolt. The second bolt is 20 feet off the ground but can be easily clipped from the ledge.

content.description: Start just to the right of Orange Oswald. Climb up the broken, left-facing corner to the anchors of Strong Arming the Little Guy.

Start on an easy corner and continue up the rounded arete to a ledge then move right and continue up the sloping holds to the anchor.

This climb is a must do for the warming up 5.10 climber.
content.protection: 6 bolts.  2 bolt anchor with rings. First bolt missing, so use a very long stick clip or trad gear.
content.location: Left facing corner on left elevated portion of Orange Oswald Wall.

content.description: Climb the face just left of the Chunko Goes Bolwing left-facing corner start. Climb straight up to the right-facing corner at the top. Climb the corner to about midway up, then step left around the arete to gain good holds that will bring you to the top.
content.protection: Two bolts at the bottom plus small to medium cams for the top.

content.description: Easy climbing leads to a thin crux from first to second bolt.  Easier climbing after.
content.protection: 4 bolts to shared chain anchor with route to the left
content.location: See beta photo below. Starts below a ledge 8 feet up. First bolt is 15 feet up but easy to reach

content.description: Climb the nice face past a couple bulges to the bolted anchor.  Not a bad face climb.
content.location: On the very left edge of the Orange Oswald Wall (actually on the face next to Orange Oswald proper), just where the trail descends to Orange Oswald and left of the ledge where Hippie Dreams begins.

climbs.name: Chunko Goes Bowling
climbs.fa: Mike Stewart, Neil Ofsthun, Dave Case 1998

content.description: Fun warm-up route for the rest of the wall.  Well bolted with a great rest about 1/3 of the way up.  The pump surprises you as you climb and you finish with a great view of the lake behind you.
content.location: Starts at flake.  Two lines to the left of Orange Oswald.

content.description: Fun moves up loose flake to gain one roof, pull a weird move, gain a tight left kneebar and rest, then pull the last roof to the upper face, pull a couple of 5.10+ moves then up easier ground to the anchors.
content.location: 2nd route right on the white ramp on the left side of this cliff.

content.description:
One of the best routes on this wall, but unless you are 6 ft you may find this route too reachy.

Locate the big sloper hold 8 feet off the deck with no holds except a good foot. You'll need some long arms to reach the start of this route. Walk into the wall with your hands up and latch on to that hold. The remainder of the route remains reachy in a few other spots especially around the 1st and 2nd bolts.

Staying direct is the best way to do this route, but by the looks of the chalk lines skirting out right around the 6 & 7th bolts avoids the small holds crux around the steeper sections of the rock. Moving out right is an option, but this way puts you too far right and a little runout so suck it up and go straight up for the real challenge, or put yourself in danger of penduluming and getting hurt.
content.location: Located in between Strong Arming the Little Guy & She Got the Bosch, I Got Drilled on the right side of the Orange Oswald Wall.
